reference: Salomon, M., Kroon, L. G., Kuik, R., & Van Wassenhove, L. N. (1991). Some extensions of the discrete lotsizing and scheduling problem. Management Science, 37(7), 801-812.
math_formula:
### Mathematical Model
Assume a production system with following elements:
- Sets: Items (I), Machines (M), Time Periods (T)
- Binary Variables: y_{imt} (production), z_{imt} (startup)
- Continuous Variables: x_{imt} (production quantity), s_{it} (inventory), b_{it} (backlog)

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\text{Minimize} && \sum_{i,m,t} (f y_{imt} + g z_{imt}) + \sum_{i,t} (h_i s_{it} + π_i b_{it}) \\
&\text{Subject to:} && s_{i,t-1} - b_{i,t-1} + \sum_m x_{imt} = d_{it} + s_{it} - b_{it} && \forall i,t \\
& && x_{imt} + ST_m z_{imt} \leq C_m y_{imt} && \forall i,m,t \\
& && \sum_i y_{imt} \leq 1 && \forall m,t \\
& && z_{imt} \geq y_{imt} - y_{i,m,t-1} && \forall i,m,t>1 \\
& && z_{im1} = y_{im1} && \forall i,m \\
& && x_{imt}, s_{it}, b_{it} \geq 0, y_{imt}, z_{imt} \in \{0,1\}
\end{aligned}
$$

Where:
- f: Setup cost
- g: Startup cost
- h_i: Holding cost for item i
- π_i: Backlogging cost for item i
- ST_m: Startup time for machine m
- C_m: Machine capacity
- d_{it}: Demand for item i in period t
natural_language_example:
Consider a food processing plant that produces multiple products on several parallel production lines:

Machines and Products:
* 3 production lines (machines)
* 5 different food products
* Each machine can only process one product type at a time

Time and Capacity:
* Planning horizon divided into 8-hour shifts
* Each machine has capacity of 100 units per shift
* 15 minutes startup time when switching products

Costs:
* Setup cost: $200 per production run
* Startup cost: $150 per product change
* Holding cost: $2 per unit per shift
* Backlog cost: $10 per unit per shift

Operational Rules:
* A machine can only produce one product type in each shift
* Product changeover requires startup time and cost
* Can hold inventory or backlog orders with associated costs

The goal is to determine:
1. Which product to produce on each machine in each shift
2. When to perform product changeovers
3. How much to produce, stock, and backlog
while minimizing total operational costs.
